answer_html: \(F(t)=1 - t^{-3}.\) Therefore, the cumulative distribution is \({\color{blue}F(t) = 1 -\frac{1}{t^3}}\)
answer_latex:
$F(t)=1 - t^{-3}.$ 
Therefore, the cumulative distribution is
${\color{blue}F(t) = 1 -\frac{1}{t^3}}$
hints_html:
How do you define the cumulative distribution function in terms of the probability density function?

Remember that the cumulative distribution function, \(F(x)\), is defined in terms of the probability density function, \(f(x)\), as follows:

\[\begin{aligned} F(t) = \int_{-\infty}^{t}f(x)\,dx.\end{aligned}\]
hints_latex:
How do you define the cumulative distribution function in terms of the
probability density function?
hints_raw:
How do you define the <b>cumulative distribution function</b> in terms of the <b>probability density function</b>?
Remember that the cumulative distribution function, <math>F(x)</math>, is defined in terms of the probability density function, <math>f(x)</math>, as follows:
:<math>
F(t) = \int_{-\infty}^{t}f(x)\,dx.
</math>
question: 1 (m)
sols_html:
Remember that the cumulative distribution function, \(F(x)\), is defined in terms of the probability density function, \(f(x)\), as follows:

\[\begin{aligned} F(t) = \int_{-\infty}^{t}f(x)\,dx.\end{aligned}\]

Hence, to determine the cumulative distribution function for the given probability density function is a matter of plugging the particular density function into the definition. (Remember that since the given density function is only defined for \(x \ge 1\), we can assume that the density function evaluates to 0 for all \(\displaystyle x < 1\)):

\[\begin{aligned} F(t) = \int_{-\infty}^{t}f(x)\,dx = \int_{1}^{t}3x^{-4}\,dx = -x^{-3}|_{1}^{t} = 1 - t^{-3}.\end{aligned}\]

Therefore, the cumulative distribution is \({\color{blue}F(t) = 1 -\frac{1}{t^3}}\)
sols_latex:
Remember that the cumulative distribution function, $F(x)$, is defined
in terms of the probability density function, $f(x)$, as follows:

\begin{align*}
F(t) = \int_{-\infty}^{t}f(x)\,dx.
\end{align*} Hence, to determine the
cumulative distribution function for the given probability density
function is a matter of plugging the particular density function into
the definition. (Remember that since the given density function is only
defined for $x \ge 1$, we can assume that the density function evaluates
to 0 for all $\displaystyle x < 1$):

\begin{align*}
F(t) = \int_{-\infty}^{t}f(x)\,dx = \int_{1}^{t}3x^{-4}\,dx = -x^{-3}|_{1}^{t} = 1 - t^{-3}.
\end{align*}
Therefore, the cumulative distribution is
${\color{blue}F(t) = 1 -\frac{1}{t^3}}$
sols_raw:
Remember that the cumulative distribution function, <math>F(x)</math>, is defined in terms of the probability density function, <math>f(x)</math>, as follows:
:<math>
F(t) = \int_{-\infty}^{t}f(x)\,dx.
</math>
Hence, to determine the cumulative distribution function for the given probability density function is a matter of plugging the particular density function into the definition. (<i>Remember that since the given density function is only defined for <math>x \ge 1</math>, we can assume that the density function evaluates to 0 for all <math>\displaystyle x < 1</math></i>):
:<math>
F(t) = \int_{-\infty}^{t}f(x)\,dx = \int_{1}^{t}3x^{-4}\,dx = -x^{-3}|_{1}^{t} = 1 - t^{-3}.
</math>
<font style="color:blue;">Therefore, the cumulative distribution is </font><math>{\color{blue}F(t) = 1 - \frac{1}{t^3}}</math>
statement_html:
Short-Answer Questions. Put your answer in the box provided but show your work also. Each question is worth 3 marks, but not all questions are of equal difficulty.

Compute the cumulative distribution function corresponding to the probability density function

\[\begin{aligned} f(x) = 3x^{-4}, \quad x \ge 1.\end{aligned}\]
